results.title: A Man of the world: H.H. the Aga Khan
results.creator_credit: Anthony de Lotbinière, Georges Robin and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
The Aga Khan is the creator of one of the world’s most dramatic and imaginative development schemes - a planned riviera along 35 miles of Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda. He is also the spiritual leader of more than 12 million Ismaili-Muslims scattered around the world, and a wealthy Parisian, racehourse owner, and Olympic skier. Shows the Aga Khan in a variety of activities. He comments personally, analysing himself and his different faces with the same detached lucidity he brings to all his undertakings.

results.title: A Man of the wilderness
results.creator_credit: Anthony de Lotbinière, BBC-TV and Georges Robin
results.brief_description: In the southern part of France there is a part which is stark because of the lack of water, and almost impossible to live off. But one man, Phillippe Lamour bought a farm in the area. During the war he cultivated his vines and made a success of it. Other Langadock farmers came to look upon him as a leader. After the end of the war he lobbied government to provide funds for an irrigation project. After 12 years of frustration the project finally started - irrigation enabled farmers to produce extra goods, their standard of living increased by 40%-50%. Lamour’s vision of agriculture, industry and tourism is now being realised.

results.title: A Man for all seasons [a discussion]
results.creator_credit: Daryl Wayland and Country Education Project
results.brief_description: Bolt’s play, set in Tudor England in the 16th century, concentrates on the battle for Tomas More’s conscience and his loyalty. Dennis O’Hearn of Melbourne University discusses the character of More, his relationships with other characters and his historical background to the play.

results.title: A Man called Edison
results.creator_credit: Dennis R. Atkinson and Spectra Pictures
results.brief_description: Presents Thomas Edison’s contributions to the motion picture industry through his early kinetoscope films. Provides a vivid panorama of early moviemaking. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: A Man and his dog
results.creator_credit: Supreme Sound Studios and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: An account of the training of Kelpie dogs in the handling of sheep on an Australian sheep station. Explains the possible origin of the breed; shows the special training a dog receives from the time he is a small pup until he can muster and control a mob of a thousand or more sheep; shows the confidence of the dog and the bond of friendship which springs up between the animals and their masters.

results.title: A Man and an organ
results.creator_credit: Peter Johnson, Film Australia and John Bushelle
results.brief_description: A filmic insight into Ronald Sharp - the self-taught builder of the Grand Organ in the Sydney Opera House. No Australian building has caught the imagination of the world as much as the Sydney Opera House. Opened in 1973 by Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth II, it was always intended that the main concert hall of this performing arts miracle building should have as its dominant, centre-stage focus a magnificent organ that would rival the splendour of the instrument in the Sydney Town Hall, the city’s biggest recital organ.

results.title: A Man's hands
results.brief_description: A witty and fast-cut montage dramatising the activities of the human hand: squeezing, poking, fixing, scratching, zipping, playing and touching. Alternatively funny and moving, entertaining and informative.
